html.h2: Step 1: Install the Splunk App for SQL Server on all Content Servers
html.p: The backend storage for SharePoint is SQL Server. Install the Splunk App for SQL Server, which is available on Splunkbase, prior to commencing work on SharePoint. Ensure that audit data fordatabase operations and perfmon data are flowing into Splunk and that all SQL Server health and performance data is being recorded and showing in the dashboards for that app prior to commencing the Splunk App for SharePoint installation. You do not need to provide the query audit for the database. Installation Documentation for the Splunk App for SQL Server is available with that app. At least Splunk App for SQL Server v0.1.8 is required.
Create the following indices in the Splunk Indexers:

In addition, you must deploy the TA-Sharepoint20XX app to the Indexers. This app is contained within the appserver/addons area of the Splunk App for SharePoint. There is a different app for SharePoint 2010 and SharePoint 2013. Only one version of the app is needed (and the data is common to both versions of SharePoint, so either one will work). You will need to restart the splunkd process to register this app on each indexer. You can disable the inputs within this app as they are not necessary.

The TA-Sharepoint20XX handles augmented line breaking and data fixing of the ULS logs so that each transaction is available as a single event instead of multiple events. This is required for exception reporting within the dashboards.
html.h2: Step 3: Designate an Inventory and Audit Reader
html.p: One of your SharePoint servers must be designated as an inventory and audit reader. This server will be used to gather the inventory information and to read the audit log within SharePoint. The Universal Forwarder that is installed on this SharePoint server will need special handling.
If you have multiple farms, then you must designate an Inventory and Audit Reader in each farm.
html.h2: Step 4: Install Splunk on the other SharePoint servers
html.p: Each SharePoint server that is not the Inventory and Audit Reader host can get a standard "Local System" type install of the latest Splunk Universal Forwarder (version v6.0 or later). It should be linked to a Splunk Deployment Server so that you can easily push updated apps to the Universal Forwarder. It should be sending data to the central Splunk instance.

html.h2: Step 8: Add Users to the SharePoint role
html.p: Part of the app install will also enable a sharepoint role. Add users that will view the SharePoint data to the sharepoint role. Without this step, they may not be able to see the relevant data. As an alternative to this process, you can also edit the eventtypes supplied with the app to indicate which index the data resides in.
We need some data from the inventory and this is gathered on a regular basis. In general, this data is collected within the first hour of operation.
There is a dashboard under Searches and Reports -> Lookup Generators called the Lookup Table Builder. Use it to generate all the lookup tables.
Log into Splunk and open the Splunk App for SharePoint. Select Health -> Farm Errors. All errors in this report are significant.

If the modular inputs show errors, they will show up in the splunkd.log file. The most common will be something to the effect "SPFarm.Local == null", which would indicate a permissions problem. Specifically, the user that is being used to run the Splunk Universal Forwarder on the Audit and Inventory reader has not been added to the SPShellAdmin list with Add-SPShellAdmin.
Replace the DOMAIN\user with the username of the user running the Splunk Universal Forwarder.
